1. Your full name: Peter Fraser

2. Your address: Geriatric Centre, Walsley, Sask.

3. Date: 9th March 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Kilsyth, Scotland

5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Fraser, M.D., F.R.S.C. (Edinburgh)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1891

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Kilsyth 1873-1879, Edinburgh 1879-1891

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get a better education, to see the world, and to acquire a piece of land, etc.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Government information. I should have already studied in a city instead of going pioneering in the wilds.
1. Your full name: Peter Fraser

2. Your address: Feriatic Centre, Walsley, Sask.

3. Date: 9th March 1969

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Kilsyth, Scotland

5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Fraser, M.D., F.R.S.C. (Edinburgh)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1891

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Kilsyth 1873-1879, Edinburgh 1879-1891

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) Eighteen years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West? You thought it was a good opportunity to see the world and to acquire a piece of land, etc.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Government information. I believe a friend in N.W.T already had a house built in a city instead of studying in the wilds.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My nieces and nephews thought I was crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Liverpool

13. What means of transportation did you use? (Jacket from Liverpool)

On 26 March on the ship Parian Stock, then the train across the Atlantic to Halifax, then the train always on a train to Yorkton, Sask.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

On the river from Halifax to Winnipeg, the twin steamed several times in the wood owing to mechanical troubles, so the passengers got out on such occasions and explored the surrounding country.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? (Was it a hotel, a tent, a shack?)

Long night at Saltcoats. At the Mann Hotel, the hotel was a new frame building unpainted.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? (Kamsack, NW4)

22-29-32 W1 N1

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Preseville, Kelvington, Sask.

When I was a student at Kelvington for three years 1919-1924, then retired.

For two years I worked for ranchers, then came back until I moved to Preseville in June 1960.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Worked in a lumber yard for three years.

Harnessed, sometimes worked on farms.

Taught at the Presbyterian Indian Mission School at Harnessed, Mont W. Whyte was principal at that time. I worked for ranchers, then came back until I moved to Preseville in June 1960.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My maiden Aunt who took care of me for twelve years did not want me to go for fear I did not know better.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Liverpool

13. What means of transportation did you use? (Rail from Liverpool on 9th March on the ship Princess 9-10th March crossing the Atlantic to Halifax, then train)

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

On the way from Halifax to Winnipeg, the train stopped several times in the wood away to meet local troubles; so the passengers got out on such occasions and explored the surrounding country.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? (Name hotel)

One night at Saltcoats. At the Mann Hotel, the hotel was a new frame building unfinished.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Kamsack, NW4

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Preceville, Kelvington, Sask

When I came to Preceville, I knew nothing about farming. For three years I worked for Mr. White, a farmer, at Humboldt, Montana. That time I learned how to farm. After returning to Preceville for two years, I then went to work at Kelvington.

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We started buying goods at local stores as soon as stores from Eaton's, Woolworth's, and other companies opened in the town. We bought mostly dry goods, flour, sugar, and other necessities. We never bought goods on credit.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1945

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

District in 1902-1903 when the KAMSACK arrived and a guard moved into the PIERREVILLE district in 1912-13.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No

I was a GP for a few years 1902-3-4

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

KAMSACK: In the year 1883, three men: Wm. Scott, Wm. Mowat and John MORIARTY were building a house near the present site of KAMSACK. They had heard of a place called KAMSACK, but they didn't know what it meant. They decided to call the place KAMSACK. The name means "a mound," John Moriarty built the first post office, then the PO was in the schoolhouse.

KAMSACK, in the year 1883, then named "Mowat's Butte."

Wm. Mowat and John Morriarty came along very late in the spring called he could not eat they asked him what place name was KAMSACK for short June a month he decided to call the place KAMSACK.

KAMSACK is the name of a mountain, John Morriarty will be the first post office, then the PC into the ground station, the first post office.
